title: 110_hr1093
content: The "Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007" increases the Medicare caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents. The Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007 amends the Social Security Act to increase caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents. The Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007 increases caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents by adjusting the total number of full-time equivalent residents in qualifying hospitals in eligible States over a 5-year period. The Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007 increases caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents by adjusting the total number of full-time equivalent residents in qualifying hospitals in eligible States. Each eligible State must have an aggregate number of increases not less than 15 and not greater than the State resident cap increase. A qualifying hospital is defined as a hospital in an eligible State that the Secretary determines should receive an increase in the limit on the total number of full-time equivalent residents. The Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007 adjusts caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents based on national and state ratios. Eligible States must meet specific criteria to receive an increase in resident positions. The Resident Physician Shortage Reduction Act of 2007 adjusts caps on graduate medical education positions for states with a shortage of residents based on national and state ratios. The National median medical resident ratio is the median of all State medical resident ratios. The State medical resident ratio is determined based on the State population. The term 'State medical resident ratio' refers to the ratio of full-time equivalent residents in approved medical residency training programs to the population of a State. The term 'State' includes a State and the District of Columbia. The Secretary considers hospital likelihood of filling resident positions when determining resident cap increases. The Secretary will consider hospital likelihood of filling new resident positions in primary care, preventive medicine, or geriatrics programs when determining resident cap increases. Additionally, amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding medical education.
